definition:
Suppose that $A$ and $B$ are smooth curves in $\mathbb{R}^n$ which pass
through a common point $P$. We say that $A$ and $B$ have zeroth order
contact if their tangents at $P$ are distinct.

Suppose that $A$ and $B$ are tangent at $P$. We may then set up a
coordinate system in which $P$ is the origin and the $x_1$ axis is
tangent to both curves. By the implicit function theorem, there will be
a neighborhood of $P$ such that $A$ can be described parametrically as
$x_i = f_i (x_1)$ with $i = 2, \ldots, n$ and $B$ can be described
parametrically as $x_i = g_i (x_1)$ with $i = 2, \ldots, n$. We then
define the *order of contact* of $A$ and $B$ at $P$ to be the largest
integer $m$ such that all partial derivatives of $f_i$ and $g_i$ of
order not greater than $m$ at $P$ are equal.
